Title: Reconstruction: Promises and Pushback, 1865–1877
Grade level: Middle school (adaptable)
Time: 50–60 minutes (plus an optional Day 2)
Driving question: What did freedom mean after the Civil War, and who got to decide?

Learning goals
- Explain the main goals and outcomes of Reconstruction.
- Identify achievements (new rights, political participation) and obstacles (Black Codes, violence, economic control).
- Cite evidence from primary sources to support a claim about whether Reconstruction was a success, a failure, or both.

Key vocabulary (teach quickly with student-friendly definitions)
- Reconstruction: Rebuilding the nation after the Civil War (1865–1877).
- Black Codes: Southern laws limiting freedoms of formerly enslaved people.
- Sharecropping: Farming system that often trapped people in debt.
- Radical Republicans: Members of Congress who pushed for equal rights and federal enforcement.
- 13th/14th/15th Amendments: Ended slavery; defined citizenship and equal protection; protected voting rights for men regardless of race.
- Ku Klux Klan (Klan): Violent groups using terror to stop Black political power.
- “Redemption”: Southern white campaign to end Reconstruction governments.

Materials
- Projector or printouts of the image for the Do Now.
- Five station documents (below), one set per group.
- Chart paper or sticky notes; markers.
- Exit ticket slips.

Lesson sequence (60 minutes)
1) Do Now (3 minutes)
Project the engraving “First Vote” by A. R. Waud (1867): Black men in line casting ballots.
Prompt: What details do you notice? What might these men be feeling? One-sentence prediction: What will help or block this new right?

2) Quick context mini-lesson (7 minutes)
On the board, timeline bullets:
- 1865: 13th Amendment; Freedmen’s Bureau; Black Codes in the South.
- 1866: Civil Rights Act; rising violence.
- 1868: 14th Amendment.
- 1867–70: Military Reconstruction Acts; Black men vote and win office.
- 1870–71: 15th Amendment; Enforcement Acts target Klan.
- 1873: Economic panic weakens support in the North.
- 1876–77: Disputed election; Compromise of 1877 ends federal enforcement; “Redemption.”

3) Vocabulary micro-teach (3 minutes)
Hit the 5–7 key terms above with one-sentence definitions.

4) Document stations (25 minutes)
- Students rotate in groups through five short sources. At each station, they answer 2 guiding questions on a “Promises vs. Obstacles” T-chart.
- Tip: 4–5 minutes per station; or split class in half and have them do three stations now, two for homework/next day.

Station A: The Reconstruction Amendments (excerpts)
- 13th (1865), Sec. 1: “Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude… shall exist within the United States…”
- 14th (1868), Sec. 1: “All persons born or naturalized… are citizens… No state shall… abridge the privileges… nor deny… equal protection of the laws.”
- 15th (1870), Sec. 1: “The right of citizens… to vote shall not be denied… on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude.”
Guiding questions:
- Which problem is each amendment trying to fix?
- How might these change daily life and politics?

Station B: Mississippi Black Code (1865) – Vagrancy law excerpt
- “All freedmen… who have no lawful employment… shall be deemed vagrants… punished by fine… and, in default of payment, hired out to any person who will pay said fine.”
Guiding questions:
- How does this limit freedom in practice?
- Who benefits and who is harmed?

Station C: Freedmen’s Bureau labor contract (sharecropping), 1866 (excerpted typical language)
- “The laborers agree to work diligently for a share of the crop… not to leave the plantation without permission… Wages or shares will be reduced for time lost.”
Guiding questions:
- What opportunities and limits do you see?
- Would this likely build independence or debt?

Station D: Abram Colby, Georgia legislator, testimony before Congress (1872) on Klan violence (excerpt)
- “They broke open my door and took me out and whipped me three hours… because I would not vote as they wanted… They said, ‘If you do not quit politics we will kill you.’”
Guiding questions:
- What was the purpose of this violence?
- How would violence affect voting and representation?

Station E: “First Vote” engraving (A. R. Waud, 1867)
- Visual analysis: setting, faces, body language.
Guiding questions:
- What does this image suggest about new rights and hopes?
- What obstacles from other stations might threaten this scene?

5) Synthesis discussion (15 minutes)
- Groups share 1 “promise” and 1 “obstacle” from their charts.
- Four Corners or Continuum Line: Place signs “Mostly a Success,” “Mixed,” “Mostly a Failure,” “Not Sure.” Students move to a position and defend with one piece of evidence from the documents.
- Push thinking: Could Reconstruction be successful in some areas (political rights) and fail in others (economic security, safety)? Who experienced it as success/failure?

6) Exit ticket (2–3 minutes)
Prompt: Make a claim: Was Reconstruction mostly a success, mostly a failure, or both? Cite evidence from two different documents.

Differentiation
- Provide sentence frames: “I claim that Reconstruction was ____ because ____. Evidence from [Doc __] shows ____. Also, [Doc __] shows ____.”
- Pair-read documents; highlight or bold key lines.
- Offer a vocabulary bank on each station sheet.
- For advanced learners: Add the question, “How did federal vs. state power shape outcomes?” or compare the 14th Amendment to a Black Code.

Classroom norms and care
- Acknowledge that some sources refer to racist violence. Tell students we’ll discuss the history honestly and respectfully, and we won’t repeat slurs. Invite students to opt out of reading aloud any distressing lines; they can summarize instead.

Assessment
- Formative: Station responses and discussion contributions.
- Exit ticket: Use a quick 3-point rubric: 1 = claim only, 2 = claim + one piece of evidence, 3 = claim + two pieces of accurate evidence and a reasoning sentence.

Optional Day 2 (45–60 minutes)
- Warm-up: Short political cartoon or quote from a Radical Republican about federal enforcement.
- Role-play “Town Hall, 1870”: Roles include a formerly enslaved farmer, a Radical Republican congressman, a Southern white planter, a Black Union veteran, a Freedmen’s Bureau agent, a white Southern Unionist, and a woman suffragist. - Nuance: Short-term political gains were real and significant; long-term protections eroded as federal enforcement ended, paving the way for Jim Crow—yet the amendments remained tools for future civil rights struggles.
